Researchers conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in human B-lymphoblastoid cells from genetically distinct individuals to investigate the role of RNA 3′-end processing in regulatory variation. They found that transcript end positions did not occur randomly in untranslated regions, but rather preferentially flanked locations of 3′ regulatory elements, including microRNA sites. The usage of these transcript length forms and motifs varied across individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and other 3′ motifs were significant predictors of expression levels of the genes in which they lay. Independent experiments confirmed the effects of polyadenylation variants on gene expression and validated the regulatory function of 3′ cis-regulatory sequence elements. The study focused on the immune regulator IRF5 and established the effect of natural variation in RNA 3′-end processing on regulatory response to antigen stimulation. The results highlight the importance of two mechanisms in the genetics of 3′-end variation: the usage of distinct 3′-end processing signals and the effects of 3′ sequence elements that determine transcript fate. The study suggests that integrating observed 3′-end positions with inferred 3′ regulatory motifs will be a critical tool in interpreting human genome variation. The findings also imply that many genetic variants with biologically relevant effects mediated by RNA 3′-end processing remain to be discovered in the human population.
A live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) vaccine, SIVΔnef, has been shown to be highly effective in inducing protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. However, the mechanisms underlying its protective efficacy are not well understood. Researchers used deep sequencing technology and comprehensive CD8 T cell epitope mapping to investigate the CD8 T cell response in SIVΔnef-vaccinated animals. They found that the initial CD8 T cell response in the acute phase of SIVΔnef infection targeted more variable epitopes, followed by widespread sequence evolution and viral escape. As a result, the CD8 T cell repertoire expanded to target highly conserved epitopes, known as anentropic specificity, and generated new responses to escaped epitope variants during the vaccination period. These findings correlated SIVΔnef-induced protection with expanded anentropic specificity and increased response depth. The researchers also demonstrated that escaped SIV-specific CD8 T cell responses were maintained as central memory CD8 T cells, contributing to the increased cumulative breadth of the CD8 T cell response at week 20 post-vaccination. Furthermore, the study showed that epitope escape and the generation of new CD8 T cell responses to these escape variants resulted in a deepening of the CD8 T cell repertoire. These results highlight the importance of anentropic specificity and repertoire depth in successful vaccine design, rendering SIVΔnef a proof-of-concept vaccine for HIV/SIV vaccine research.
Interleukin-1 (IL-1) plays a crucial role in coordinating the neutrophil response to Candida albicans infections in the oral mucosa. Research using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) has shown that IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) signaling is essential for controlling fungal growth and dissemination. IL-1R signaling regulates the neutrophil response in two ways: by recruiting circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and by mobilizing newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow. Mice deficient in IL-1R (Il1r1-/-) displayed impaired neutrophil recruitment and defective fungal control, leading to increased fungal loads in the tongue.

The study found that IL-1R signaling is critical for the production of neutrophil-chemotactic factors by epithelial cells, which attracts neutrophils to the site of infection. Additionally, IL-1R signaling regulates the production of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in the circulation, which is essential for neutrophil mobilization from the bone marrow. Endothelial cells were identified as the primary source of G-CSF during OPC, responding to IL-1α released from keratinocytes in the infected tissue. This IL-1-dependent crosstalk between keratinocytes and endothelial cells was confirmed in vitro using a novel murine tongue-derived keratinocyte cell line and an established endothelial cell line. These findings establish a new link between IL-1 and granulopoiesis in the context of fungal infection, highlighting the importance of IL-1R signaling in preventing fungal growth and dissemination in the oral mucosa.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals in 48 endemic countries through annual mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-filarial drugs. This significant achievement resulted in an estimated $21.8 billion in economic benefits over the lifetime of 31.4 million individuals treated during the first 8 years of the program. The economic benefits were calculated by quantifying the number of clinical manifestations averted and analyzing the savings associated with disease prevention in terms of direct treatment costs, indirect costs of lost labor, and costs to the health system.

The study found that the protection of nearly 3 million newborns and other individuals from acquiring lymphatic filariasis resulted in over $2.3 billion in economic benefits. Additionally, the halting of the progression of the disease in over 28 million individuals already infected with LF resulted in an associated lifetime economic benefit of approximately $19.5 billion. Furthermore, decreased patient services associated with reduced LF morbidity saved the health systems of endemic countries approximately $2.2 billion. The study concludes that MDA for LF offers significant economic benefits, with a high economic rate of return, making the GPELF an excellent investment in global health.
Researchers have developed a new animal model to study Gaucher disease (GD), a lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene. The model, created in medaka fish, displays characteristics similar to the neuronopathic form of GD in humans, including the accumulation of Gaucher cells in the brain, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Unlike humans and mice with GBA mutations, the medaka fish survived for months, allowing researchers to study the disease progression.

The study found that GBA mutations lead to lysosomal dysfunction in neurons and the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. However, disrupting α-syn did not improve the life span, axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in the medaka fish. This suggests that α-syn may not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of neuronopathic GD.

The researchers also found that GBA mutations are associated with an increased risk of developing Parkinson's disease (PD), a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of α-syn in the brain. The study highlights the importance of understanding the pathological mechanisms of GBA mutations and the development of novel therapies for GD and PD. The medaka model provides a valuable tool for studying the disease progression and testing potential treatments.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to Listeria monocytogenes, a type of bacteria that can live inside host cells. They found that when L. monocytogenes is contained within a phagosome, a type of cellular compartment, it suppresses the immune response. This suppression is not due to inefficient antigen presentation, but rather a direct effect on the adaptive immune response. The study showed that the presence of phagosome-confined L. monocytogenes limits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and leads to the rapid production of IL-10, a cytokine that can suppress the immune response. The researchers found that blocking the IL-10 receptor or the absence of MyD88, a protein involved in the immune response, restored protective immunity. This suggests that the presence of microbes within a phagosome can impact the innate and adaptive immune response by antagonizing the signaling pathways necessary for inflammation and the generation of protective CD8 T cells. The study also found that co-infection with phagosome-confined and cytosolic L. monocytogenes prevented the generation of acquired immunity and limited the expansion of antigen-specific T cells. These findings have implications for understanding how microbes interact with the immune system and controlling their pathogenic effects.
Researchers have identified genetic variants associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), a leading cause of blindness worldwide. The study focused on the SIX6 gene, which plays a role in ocular development and has been linked to the morphology of the optic nerve. By sequencing the SIX6 gene in 262 POAG cases and 256 controls, the researchers found six nonsynonymous coding variants, including one common variant, Asn141His (rs33912345), which was significantly associated with POAG. The variants were tested in a zebrafish model to evaluate their effects on eye development. The results showed that five variants, primarily found in POAG cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth variant, found only in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX6 enhancer increased expression of SIX6 and disrupted its regulation. Furthermore, the study found that patients homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele (His141) had a thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than those homozygous for the non-risk allele (Asn141). This suggests that SIX6 risk variants may disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells and an increased risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss. The findings provide new insights into the genetic mechanisms underlying POAG and highlight the importance of the SIX6 gene in ocular development.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch, known as the flagellar switch, that controls the production of flagella and toxins in the human intestinal pathogen Clostridium difficile. This switch, located upstream of the flgB operon, is a 154-base pair invertible sequence flanked by 21-base pair inverted repeats. The orientation of the flagellar switch determines whether the bacteria express flagellum and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete toxins. When the switch is in the "flg phase ON" orientation, bacteria express flagellar and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete toxins. In contrast, when the switch is in the "flg phase OFF" orientation, bacteria are attenuated for flagellar and toxin gene expression, are aflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion.

The researchers found that the orientation of the flagellar switch is reversible during growth in vitro and that a C. difficile-specific regulatory factor is required to destabilize or degrade the early flagellar gene mRNA when the flagellar switch is in the OFF orientation. The tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at the cwpV switch, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions. The flagellar switch affects transcription of the toxin genes by way of σD, impacting the production of the glucosylating toxins and the cytotoxicity of C. difficile. The findings suggest that flagellar motility and toxin production are subject to phase variation in C. difficile, identifying an additional level of regulation of these linked processes.
Researchers studied the process of spore formation in Clostridium difficile, a bacterium that causes intestinal infections. This process, called endosporulation, results in a highly resistant spore that is central to the bacterium's infectious cycle. The study focused on the sigma factors, proteins that regulate gene expression during spore formation. In the model organism Bacillus subtilis, four sigma factors (σF, σE, σG, and σK) are known to control gene expression in the forespore and mother cell during endosporulation.

The researchers found that the genes for these sigma factors are conserved in spore-forming bacteria, including Clostridium difficile. However, the study revealed differences in the function and timing of the sigma factors in C. difficile compared to B. subtilis. Specifically, the activity of σE was found to be partially independent of σF, and σG activity was not dependent on σE. Additionally, the activity of σK did not require σG, and σK was not strictly necessary for the formation of heat-resistant spores.

The study suggests that the top level of the endosporulation network is conserved across species, with the sigma factors acting as key regulators of the pathway. However, the results also indicate reduced temporal segregation between the activities of the early and late sigma factors in C. difficile compared to B. subtilis. The findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of endosporulation and the role of sigma factors in this process.
Researchers have developed a new framework to model the behavior of proteins with multiple sites that can be modified, such as through phosphorylation. This framework, called the Monod-Wyman-Changeux (MWC) model, simplifies complex systems by using a single variable to describe the protein's activity. The MWC model can accurately replicate the behavior of more detailed models and is useful for analyzing systems where multiple proteins interact simultaneously. The researchers applied this framework to a newly discovered cell size checkpoint in budding yeast, which measures cell growth by monitoring signals at the plasma membrane. They found that the known components of this pathway can form a robust hysteretic switch, meaning that the response is all-or-none and triggered only when the signal reaches a certain threshold. This system consists of a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response. The MWC model can also be extended to other types of multisite modifications, such as ligand binding, transcription factor regulation, and ubiquitination. The researchers demonstrated the versatility of the MWC model by applying it to a detailed mechanistic model of the cell size checkpoint. The model assumes that the protein is phosphorylated by a kinase at multiple sites and dephosphorylated by a phosphatase, and that the system is nonsequential, meaning that there are different phosphoforms of the protein.
Researchers have made significant progress in understanding the quorum sensing (QS) system of E. coli, a mechanism that enables bacteria to communicate and coordinate their behavior. Quorum sensing is a complex process that involves the interplay of multiple regulatory components, making it challenging to decipher its underlying mechanisms. To tackle this complexity, scientists employed a "bottom-up" approach, breaking down the QS system into smaller sub-networks and analyzing each component separately. This approach allowed them to identify a new negative feedback interaction and reveal the crucial role of the LsrR regulator in the QS "switch" of E. coli.

The researchers used a combination of experimental work and mathematical modeling to study the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) QS system in E. coli. They separated the network architecture into sub-networks and examined the propagation of the native signal molecule, AI-2. By analyzing each module separately, they were able to identify new regulatory interactions within the network and construct a hypothetical model of the system. This model was used to simulate the behavior of the intact network and its sub-systems, providing a mechanistic understanding of the interplay among regulatory sub-structures.

The study highlights the importance of using a bottom-up approach to analyze complex biological networks, particularly when positive and negative regulations exist within the network architecture. This approach allowed the researchers to uncover the determinant role of LsrR in the E. coli QS "switch," which was previously masked by interfering regulatory loops. The findings of this study have implications for understanding QS network architectures and may guide the development of new biotechnological applications.
Researchers conducted a study in rural Gabon to investigate the impact of schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma haematobium, on the prevalence and incidence of Plasmodium falciparum infection in school-age children. The study found that schistosomiasis tends to increase the risk of Plasmodium infection, but when combined with soil-transmitted helminths (STH), such as Trichuris trichiura or hookworm, the risk of Plasmodium infection is significantly increased. The study also found that the incidence of malaria was higher in children infected with Schistosoma haematobium compared to those who were not infected, with a significant delay in the time-to-first-malaria event in children aged 6-10 years. The results suggest that STH enhance the risk of Plasmodium infection in schistosomiasis-positive children, and that schistosomiasis increases susceptibility to developing malaria in young children but not in older children. The study highlights the importance of considering STH and schistosomiasis control as an additional tool in malaria control programs in areas where these infections are co-endemic.
Researchers investigated the role of the transcription factor IRF-5 in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during Leishmania donovani infection. They found that IRF-5-induced inflammation limits CD8+ T cell expansion and induces hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α) in dendritic cells. HIF-1α impairs dendritic cell functions, leading to a decrease in IL-12 expression and an increase in IL-10 expression. This results in a higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8+ T cells and reduced CD8+ T cell expansion. Mice with a targeted depletion of HIF-1α in dendritic cells had a significantly lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting that HIF-1α induction is an immune-evasive mechanism adopted by Leishmania parasites to establish persistent infections. The study suggests that IRF-5-mediated inflammation at early stages of infection plays a detrimental role in the development of protective CD8+ T cell responses. The findings indicate that targeting HIF-1α in dendritic cells may be a potential therapeutic strategy to enhance CD8+ T cell responses and control Leishmania infection.
Researchers conducted a meta-analysis to identify risk factors for adverse prognosis and death in American visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a disease with high fatality rates in Latin America. The study analyzed 14 studies from Brazil, which were selected from a comprehensive survey of 2,945 studies. The researchers used a tool to evaluate the methodological quality of the studies and synthesized information on prognostic variables using meta-analysis.

The strongest predictors of adverse prognosis and death in VL patients were identified as jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 and over 40-50 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. Edema and low hemoglobin concentration were also associated with unfavorable outcomes. The study found that Leishmania-HIV coinfection was a significant prognostic factor, with coinfected individuals having a higher risk of poor prognosis.

The researchers noted that the lack of reduction in fatality rates of VL in Brazil can be attributed to limitations in therapy, delayed diagnosis, and inadequate management of high-risk patients. The study suggests that identifying prognostic factors associated with VL can be a valuable tool for clinical practice. However, the development of externally validated prognostic models is a priority for future research, as the current models lack validation procedures. The study highlights the need for improved management of VL patients, particularly those at higher risk of unfavorable outcomes.
Researchers in Algeria investigated the susceptibility of Leishmania parasites to antimony, a common treatment for visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, over a 30-year period. The study analyzed 106 isolates from humans, dogs, rodents, and phlebotomines collected between 1976 and 2013 in Algeria, as well as 18 isolates from dogs in France. The researchers determined the 50% inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of potassium antimony tartrate (Sb(III)) and sodium stibogluconate (Sb(V)) in promastigotes and intramacrophage amastigotes, respectively. The study found a trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in visceral leishmaniasis (VL) isolates during the 30-year period, but an increase in the frequency of insusceptible (S-) phenotypes in cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) isolates was observed. The emergence of S- phenotypes was associated with the inclusion of Leishmania killicki (syn: L. tropica) isolates, which cause cutaneous leishmaniasis and have emerged in Algeria in the last decade. The study highlights the need for an effective methodology to determine the antimony susceptibility status of Leishmania isolates to detect the emergence of and prevent the dissemination of drug-resistant strains. The results provide insight into the spatiotemporal dynamics of Leishmania antimony susceptibility in Algeria and emphasize the importance of preserving the therapeutic efficiency of antimonials to cure leishmaniasis.
Researchers have investigated the link between acute infectious gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition. They found that exposure to certain foodborne pathogens, such as Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacter rodentium, can increase the risk of CD in individuals colonized with a specific type of bacteria called adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC). AIEC is a pathobiont, a type of bacteria that normally resides in the gut but can contribute to disease under certain conditions.

The study used two new models to examine the relationship between acute infectious gastroenteritis and CD in mice colonized with AIEC. The results showed that AIEC-colonized mice that developed infectious gastroenteritis had a worse outcome compared to AIEC-naive animals exposed to the same infection. The researchers found that the tissue-associated expansion of AIEC in the post-infectious period was driven by the bacteria's resistance to host defense peptides and a strong inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen.

Immunohistochemical analysis revealed a significant increase in immune cells in the gut of AIEC-colonized mice after infectious gastroenteritis, indicating a heightened inflammatory environment. The study suggests that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for CD onset. The findings identify AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, which could be targeted in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals.
Researchers have identified a gene called Lachesis (LIS) that plays a crucial role in determining the fate of cells in the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis, a flowering plant. The female gametophyte contains two gametic cells, the egg cell and the central cell, which are essential for fertilization, as well as five accessory cells. However, the mechanisms that control the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate were previously unknown.

The researchers isolated a mutant called lachesis (lis) that forms supernumerary egg cells, indicating that LIS is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic cell fate. In lis mutants, accessory cells differentiate into gametic cells, suggesting that LIS represses gametic cell fate in accessory cells. The temporal and spatial pattern of LIS expression suggests that this mechanism is generated in gametic cells.

Further analysis revealed that LIS is homologous to the yeast splicing factor PRP4, indicating that components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions. The lis-1 mutant phenotype shows two levels of cell fate regulation: one between gametic and accessory cells, and one between egg and central cell. The late initiation of cell-specific marker genes indicates that distinct cell fates are only manifested after cellularization. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms controlling cell fate decisions in the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in a rural highland Ethiopian community to understand the barriers to wearing shoes, which is crucial for preventing Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs). The study used the PRECEDE-PROCEED model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, educational, and ecological factors influencing shoe use among children. The researchers gathered information from 242 respondents through focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and extended case studies.

The study found that shoe-wearing norms are changing in the community, with going barefoot becoming increasingly seen as "shameful." However, many practical and social barriers prevent people from wearing shoes regularly. Limited financial resources make it difficult for people to purchase and maintain shoes, leading to shoes being reserved for special occasions. As a result, children often do not receive shoes until they reach a certain age.

The study identified several barriers to shoe wearing, including financial constraints, poor suitability of shoes for daily activities, and low risk perception of NTDs. These barriers are likely to be relevant to a range of NTDs, not just podoconiosis, a disease triggered by exposure to irritant soils in the tropical highlands. The study suggests that targeting individuals' beliefs and attitudes about shoe wearing could be an effective way to improve shoe use and prevent NTDs. The findings have implications for those implementing footwear programs and highlight the need to address underlying structural barriers related to poverty.
The pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us9 protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of dissociated sympathetic neurons. Research has shown that Us9 null mutants are defective in anterograde transmission of infection in vivo. To understand how Us9 promotes axonal sorting of viral proteins, scientists investigated the association of Us9 with lipid rafts on the surface of infected cells. Lipid rafts are microdomains on the cell membrane that are rich in cholesterol and play a key role in protein sorting and trafficking.

The study found that Us9 is associated with lipid rafts and that this association is critical for Us9-mediated sorting of viral structural proteins. In non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a rat pheochromocytoma cell line that mimics sympathetic neurons, Us9 was highly enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing the affinity of Us9 for lipid rafts inhibited anterograde transmission of infection from sympathetic neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. These findings suggest that association of Us9 with lipid rafts is essential for efficient targeting of structural proteins to axons and directional spread of PRV from pre-synaptic to post-synaptic neurons and cells of the mammalian nervous system. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of alpha herpesvirus transmission and highlights the importance of lipid rafts in viral protein sorting and trafficking.
Researchers have found that genetically identical cells of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae exhibit variations in growth rate and stress tolerance, a phenomenon known as nongenetic heterogeneity. This variation is significant in clinical contexts, such as within tumors and microbial infections, where cells show differences in growth rate and susceptibility to drugs or stress. The study aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanism underlying this nongenetic heterogeneity in yeast cells.

Using genetic and chemical perturbations, combined with high-throughput single-cell assays, the researchers found that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, acting through the Ras/cAMP/protein kinase A (PKA) pathway and its target transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4, underlies this nongenetic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, and an endogenous reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. The paralogs Msn2 and Msn4 differ in their roles in nongenetic heterogeneity, with Msn2 required for heterogeneity in expression of Tsl1, a subunit of trehalose synthase that contributes to acute-stress tolerance.

Perturbing nongenetic heterogeneity by mutating genes in this pathway or by culturing wild-type cells with the cell-permeable cAMP analog 8-bromo-cAMP or the PKA inhibitor H89 significantly impacts survival of acute heat stress. The results suggest that the Ras/cAMP/PKA pathway, acting through Msn2 and Msn4, underlies nongenetic heterogeneity in yeast-cell growth and stress tolerance, and that manipulating this pathway may provide a means of defeating bet-hedging pathogens or tumor cells by making them more uniformly susceptible to treatment.
Researchers analyzed the genetic diversity of the Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) during an outbreak in the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique in 2013-2014. They used deep-sequencing technologies to study the viral genetic diversity present in infected individuals and understand how the virus may have evolved during the outbreak. The analysis revealed changes in the consensus sequence and a diverse range of minority variants present at various levels in the population. The researchers also found that the overall diversity of the virus was reduced after a single passage in cell lines. Furthermore, they constructed an infectious clone of the virus and identified a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure not previously found in nature, which led to increased replication in insect cells. This new UTR structure was unique among circulating CHIKV strains worldwide. The study highlights the need for continued viral diversity surveillance over time to understand the evolutionary potential of CHIKV. The research provides an in-depth look at the minority variants present during the outbreak, identifying novel variants and structural elements. The findings suggest that CHIKV has rapidly evolved in a short period of time since entering the naive population in the Americas. The study's results agree with previous research, placing the viruses in the Asian Lineage of CHIKV and clustering with the St. Martin strain CNR20236.
Researchers have identified a previously unannotated gene called UBTOR, which plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and the mTOR signaling pathway. mTOR signaling is involved in various human diseases, including cancer. The study found that reducing UBTOR function in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells promotes neurite outgrowth and cell growth. Conversely, overexpressing UBTOR suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Mechanistic studies revealed that UBTOR stabilizes DEPTOR, a component of the mTOR complex, to inhibit mTOR signaling. In zebrafish models, disrupting the UBTOR gene upregulates mTOR signaling and promotes tumor formation induced by the HRAS G12V mutation. Furthermore, UBTOR depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenograft mouse model. These findings demonstrate that UBTOR regulates cell growth and neoplasia through mTOR signaling. The study also showed that UBTOR interacts with DEPTOR and mTOR complexes, and that NGF treatment upregulates UBTOR expression. The results suggest that UBTOR may play a role in keeping mTOR signaling activity in check. Overall, the study highlights the importance of UBTOR in regulating cell growth and neoplasia, and its potential as a target for cancer therapy.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein complexes in the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes human African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness. This parasite is highly diverged from well-studied eukaryotes, making it difficult to determine the functions of many of its proteins. To address this challenge, the researchers used biochemical fractionation to systematically study the interactions of over 3,300 protein groups in the procyclic life stage of T. brucei. Their analysis identified 128 high-confidence complexes, including 635 previously uncharacterized proteins, and validated the functions of several novel proteins associated with the RNA-editing machinery. The study provides an unprecedented view of the protein complex map of T. brucei and serves as a reliable resource for further characterization of trypanosomatid proteins. The researchers used this map to reveal novel factors involved in the mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei and validated their findings through independent experiments. This study presents the largest proteomics-based interaction map of trypanosomatid parasites to date, offering a valuable resource for formulating new biological hypotheses and experimental leads.
Researchers studied lymph nodes (LNs) in macaques infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the bacteria that cause tuberculosis. They found that LNs are not just sites where the immune system fights infection, but also where Mtb bacteria can persist for a long time. The study used PET CT scans to track inflammation in LNs and found that LNs in infected macaques showed increased metabolic activity early in the infection. At the time of death, almost all LNs with high metabolic activity contained live Mtb bacteria or Mtb DNA.

The researchers compared two types of macaques, cynomolgus and rhesus, and found that rhesus macaques were more susceptible to Mtb infection due to more extensive LN pathology. However, Mtb grew to the same level in LNs of both macaque species, but cynomolgus macaques were able to control the infection better than rhesus macaques. LNs were found to be poor at killing Mtb, even with treatment, and the formation of granulomas in LNs disrupted their structure and allowed Mtb to persist.

The study suggests that LNs play a crucial role in the persistence of Mtb infection, and that their structure and function are affected by the infection. The findings have implications for understanding how Mtb infection progresses and how it can be treated. Overall, the study highlights the importance of LNs in the immune response to Mtb infection and the need for further research into the role of LNs in tuberculosis.
Researchers have identified a large collection of novel microsporidia, a type of fungus-related intracellular pathogen, that infect nematodes, a group of worm-like animals. These microsporidia were isolated from wild nematodes, including Caenorhabditis elegans, a commonly used model organism in scientific research. The study found that Nematocida parisii is the most common microsporidia infecting C. elegans in the wild, and six new species in the Nematocida genus were identified. Additionally, two new subclades, Enteropsectra and Pancytospora, were discovered, which are genetically distinct from Nematocida and belong to the main clade of microsporidia that includes human pathogens. The microsporidia were found to infect intestinal cells, except for Pancytospora epiphaga, which replicates in the epidermis of its host. The study also showed that some microsporidia have broad host specificity, while others have narrow host specificity. For example, some microsporidia can infect Oscheius tipulae but not its sister species Oscheius sp. 3, and vice versa. Furthermore, the study found that Nematocida ausubeli has evolved mechanisms to prevent the induction of a host response in C. elegans. The discovery of these novel microsporidia and their diverse interactions with nematodes provides a rich resource for investigating host-parasite coevolution in tractable nematode hosts.
Chemokine receptors, a type of G protein-coupled receptor, play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis and HIV infection. Research has shown that homo- and heterodimers of chemokine receptors, such as CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2, can modulate receptor function. However, the structural information about these dimers and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the homo- and heterodimerization patterns of these receptors at an atomic level. The results show that the closely related CC chemokine receptors, CCR5 and CCR2, have similar homodimerization patterns, but differ significantly from CXCR4. Despite their high sequence identity, cholesterol modulates the CC homodimer interfaces in a subtype-specific manner. The study also found distinct dimerization patterns for CXCR4/CCR5 and CXCR4/CCR2 heterodimers, with CXCR4/CCR5 showing increased cholesterol sensitivity. This research provides a comprehensive structural overview of the complex interaction network between chemokine receptors and highlights how heterodimerization and interaction with the membrane environment diversifies the function of closely related G protein-coupled receptors. The findings suggest that cholesterol can increase the dynamic range and versatility of associations between closely related transmembrane receptors.
Researchers have identified a previously unknown form of systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite. This new form, referred to as "atypical" systemic leishmaniasis, presents with a range of symptoms that differ from the classical form of the disease. In the classical form, patients typically experience prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and wasting. In contrast, patients with atypical systemic leishmaniasis may exhibit symptoms such as lymphadenopathy (enlargement of the lymph nodes) and anemia, but lack one or two of the classical symptoms.

A study of 160 patients with suspected immune deficiency found that 19.4% had normal laboratory profiles, but their macrophages (a type of immune cell) were infected with Leishmania parasites. This discovery revealed the presence of atypical systemic leishmaniasis, which can masquerade as a condition with a non-functional immune system. As a result, patients with this form of the disease are prone to recurrent secondary infections, leading to a wide range of symptoms.

The study also found that atypical systemic leishmaniasis is not limited to the pediatric age group, as adults were also affected. The researchers recommend that healthcare providers consider atypical systemic leishmaniasis in patients with unexplained depressed immunity and no obvious immunologic defect. This new form of the disease is more common than previously thought and presents a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected.
Researchers have analyzed millions of mutations and polymorphisms in human populations to identify potential predictors of disease, drug reactions, microbial infections, and age-related conditions. However, predicting the phenotypic consequences of a sequence variant is a complex task. A new study has explored the potential of variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins to identify polymorphisms with likely phenotypic consequences. The researchers assembled a collection of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and HGMD databases and identified pairs of sequence variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins. The study found that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins, and if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. This information can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide a suite of candidates for further diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The researchers also found that sequence variants co-occur at aligned amino acid pairs more frequently than expected by chance, suggesting that similar functional constraints on paralogous protein sequences result in coordinated distributions of both disease and non-disease-causing variants along their lengths. This study provides a novel resource for functional genomics and suggests that paralogous human genes can be used to identify new disease gene candidates and uncharacterized variants likely to have phenotypic consequences.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum in patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria. They used a technique called RNA sequencing to analyze gene expression in 44 parasite isolates from Papuan patients. The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had altered gene expression compared to those causing uncomplicated malaria. Specifically, they found that severe malaria parasites had decreased glycolysis, altered chromatin structure, and reduced expression of surface antigens called PfEMP1. PfEMP1s are major targets of protective immunity.

The study also identified novel associations between disease severity and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments. These findings suggest that parasites adapt to or are selected by the host environment in severe malaria. The researchers found that severe malaria parasites down-regulated genes involved in PfEMP1 surface expression, which may explain why immunity to severe malaria is acquired more rapidly than immunity to uncomplicated malaria. The study's results will inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria and provide insights into how the parasite responds to the host environment in severe malaria. The findings also suggest that the parasite's surface antigens may play a key role in the development of severe malaria.
Researchers have explored a promising approach to prevent HIV-1 infection by delivering potent, broadly-neutralizing antibodies using an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector. In a study, rhesus monkeys were given AAV-delivered anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) in IgG1 form, achieving persisting levels of up to 270 micrograms per milliliter. However, host antibody responses to the delivered antibody were observed in nine of the 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration of delivered antibody. Despite this, the six monkeys in the AAV-5L7 IgG1 mAb group showed significant protective effects against the SIVmac239 challenge virus, including lower viral load at peak height and set point, and a delay in the time to peak viral load. Notably, one monkey with the highest level of delivered 5L7 mAb resisted six successive SIVmac239 challenges, including a final challenge with a high dose of infectious virus. This study demonstrates the potential of AAV-delivered antibodies for HIV-1 prevention, but highlights the need to overcome the problem of anti-antibody responses for this approach to be effective. AAV vectors have been shown to be safe and effective in human gene therapy trials, and have the potential to deliver proteins at stable levels for years. The study suggests that AAV-delivered antibodies could provide a sterilizing barrier to HIV-1 infection, but further research is needed to address the issue of anti-antibody responses.
Research on protein dynamics has traditionally relied on the assumption that proteins respond linearly to thermal noise and structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment. However, a study of two motor proteins, myosin V and kinesin KIF1A, has found that this assumption is not always valid. The researchers used a coarse-grained elastic network approximation to investigate the conformational relaxation properties of these proteins and discovered that nonlinear effects play a significant role in their dynamics.

The study found that the normal mode description, which is commonly used to analyze protein dynamics, fails to accurately describe the conformational motions of KIF1A. In contrast, myosin V's slow conformational relaxation motions can still be qualitatively characterized in terms of normal modes. Despite the breakdown of the normal mode description, the researchers found that both proteins exhibit ordered and robust mechanochemical motions, which are conformational relaxation processes that follow an energetic activation.

Large-scale conformational changes in proteins, such as those caused by ligand binding, are often considered in the framework of linear response theory and normal mode approximation. However, the study's findings suggest that nonlinear effects are essential for understanding the dynamics of motor proteins like myosin V and KIF1A. The results indicate that important assumptions in the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered.
Researchers have investigated the complex interactions between different endocytic pathways in cells. Endocytosis is the process by which cells take in substances from outside their membranes. Clathrin-independent endocytosis is a type of endocytosis that does not involve the protein clathrin. The study found that specific proteins called caveolins and cavins, which are part of structures called caveolae, can regulate clathrin-independent endocytosis. Caveolins and cavins were found to inhibit the clathrin-independent carriers/GPI-AP enriched early endosomal compartment (CLIC/GEEC) endocytic pathway, which is a type of clathrin-independent endocytosis. This inhibition occurs independently of the formation of caveolae, which are the structures that caveolins and cavins are part of. The study also found that the CLIC/GEEC pathway is upregulated in cells lacking caveolins and cavins, suggesting that these proteins play a role in regulating this pathway. Furthermore, the study found that caveolins can inhibit the CLIC/GEEC pathway even when they are not part of caveolae, and that this inhibition is associated with changes in the movement of lipid molecules in the cell membrane. The study also found that cavins can modulate the activity of a key regulator of the CLIC/GEEC pathway, called Cdc42. Overall, the study provides new insights into the regulation of clathrin-independent endocytosis and the role of caveolins and cavins in this process.
Researchers have identified a subset of Receiver (REC) domains, known as Aspartate-Less Receiver (ALR) domains, which lack the conserved aspartate (Asp) residue typically phosphorylated by sensory histidine kinases in two-component signaling systems. These systems are crucial for sensing and responding to environmental stimuli in bacteria, Archaea, and plants. By analyzing deposited REC domain sequences, the researchers found that ALRs are surprisingly common, comprising approximately 4% of all REC domains, or about 2 per completed genome in bacteria. ALRs are often associated with rare effector outputs and have reorganized their active pockets to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate input signals other than Asp phosphorylation. This reorganization allows them to retain the canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimeric interface. Some ALRs have diversified to accommodate signaling inputs from small molecules, such as antibiotics, or Ser-Thr phosphorylation through bacterial eukaryotic-like Ser-Thr kinases and their cognate PP2C phosphatases, which regulate crucial cell envelope-related functions and virulence in many microbes. The study defines ALRs as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into shared mechanisms of activation between ALR and REC domains. The researchers identified various substitutions at the conserved phospho-Asp site, including Ser, Thr, Tyr, Arg, and Cys, which have the potential for phospho-regulation by different kinases and phosphatases.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes simplex virus (oHSV) that targets cancer cells by retargeting to specific receptors, such as HER2, which is overexpressed in various cancers. Unlike traditional oHSVs, these new viruses are fully virulent and retain their ability to replicate in cancer cells while sparing other cells in the tumor. The study investigated the safety and efficacy of a HER2-retargeted, fully virulent oHSV armed with interleukin-12 (IL-12) in immunocompetent mice. The results showed that the virus, named R-115, had a high safety profile and inhibited the growth of primary HER2-expressing tumors. Moreover, mice that survived the primary tumor treatment were protected from the growth of untreated contralateral tumors, indicating an abscopal immunotherapeutic effect. Analysis of the local response revealed that R-115 unleashed an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines and promoting Th1 polarization. Tumor-infiltrating cells, such as CD4+ and CD335+ cells, were increased in all responder mice, while CD8+, Foxp3+, and CD141+ cells were increased and CD11b+ cells were decreased in R-115-treated mice. The study demonstrated a durable response, including a breakage of tolerance towards both HER2 and wild-type tumor cells, and underscored a systemic immunotherapeutic vaccine response. These findings suggest that R-115 has potential as a therapeutic agent for cancer treatment.
A recent study investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. Researchers compared the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by adenovirus 5 (Ad5) and canarypox viral vector (ALVAC) to HIV. The study found that Ad5-specific CD4 T cells were readily susceptible to HIV, while ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells were substantially less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. The lower HIV susceptibility of ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells was associated with reduced surface expression of HIV entry co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on these cells. Additionally, ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells displayed a strong Th1 phenotype, producing higher levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (MIP-β) but little IL-17. The study also found that ALVAC and Ad5 vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 vs. CD4 T-cell proliferative responses in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC). Depletion of ALVAC-induced CD8 T cells in PBMC led to a modest increase in HIV infection of vector-specific CD4 T cells, suggesting a role of ALVAC-specific CD8 T cells in protecting ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells from HIV. These findings highlight the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination and suggest that the choice of vaccine vector may impact the susceptibility of CD4 T cells to HIV infection.
Researchers investigated the evolution of X inactivation strategies in mammals, a process where one X chromosome is silenced in female somatic cells. They found that the choice of which X chromosome to silence varies among species, ranging from strict paternally inherited X inactivation (PXI) to unbiased random X inactivation (RXI). PXI renders females haploid for all maternally inherited alleles, while RXI equalizes expression of maternally and paternally inherited alleles in each female tissue.

The study used a theoretical population genetic analysis to examine how conditions such as dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence the evolution of X inactivation strategies. The results showed that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selection can select for a broad range of X inactivation strategies, including unequal rates of inactivation between maternally and paternally inherited X chromosomes.

The study found that RXI is favored over PXI as long as alleles deleterious to female fitness are sufficiently recessive. However, the criteria for RXI evolution are more restrictive when fitness variation is sexually antagonistic, meaning alleles deleterious to females are beneficial to males. Evolutionary transitions from PXI to RXI generally increase mean relative female fitness at the expense of decreased male fitness. The study provides a theoretical framework for predicting and interpreting the evolution of chromosome-wide expression of X-linked genes and makes several predictions that could motivate future studies of allele-specific gene expression variation.
Researchers investigated the antiviral properties of a host protein called zinc-finger antiviral protein (ZAP) against three flaviviruses: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, but not DENV or ZIKV, and that depleting ZAP enhanced JEV replication. The study revealed that ZAP targets JEV for degradation by the 3'-5' RNA exosome complex and hampers viral translation. The zinc-finger motifs of ZAP are essential for its antiviral activity against JEV. The researchers identified the 3'-untranslated region (UTR) of JEV, particularly a region with dumbbell structures and high CG dinucleotide content, as the binding site for ZAP. This interaction confers sensitivity to ZAP. The study suggests that ZAP may act as an intrinsic antiviral factor by binding to specific RNA sequences to combat JEV infection. The findings indicate that JEV is the first flavivirus sensitive to human ZAP, providing new insights into the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against viral RNA without a 3'-poly(A) tail. The study also suggests that 3'-5' RNA degradation by the exosome complex is involved in the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against JEV infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a significant human and animal pathogen that causes severe disease, including hemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Researchers investigated the host response to RVFV infection in mice to understand the virus's pathogenesis. They compared the immune response to wild-type RVFV strain ZH501 and the attenuated vaccine strain MP-12 in C57BL/6 mice. The study found that mice infected with live-attenuated MP-12 survived the infection with minimal clinical disease and a low cytokine response. In contrast, wild-type ZH501 infection was lethal, causing lymphopenia, platelet depletion, and a strong systemic cytokine response, which correlated with high virus titers and significant tissue pathology. The liver was found to be a primary target of RVFV infection, with significant clinical and histological data supporting this finding. However, a pro-inflammatory response was not observed in the liver, but rather a chemokine response indicating the infiltration of immunoreactive cells. In the brains of infected mice, a significant chemokine and pro-inflammatory cytokine response was evident, but with little pathology indicating meningoencephalitis. The study suggests that RVFV pathogenesis in mice is associated with liver dysfunction due to necrosis and hepatitis, while the long-term course of disease is neurologic in nature, supported by observations of human disease and the BALB/c mouse model.
Chemotherapy resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) poses a significant challenge to improving patient survival. Researchers investigated the mechanisms of taxane chemoresistance in TNBC and found that C-C motif chemokine ligand 20 (CCL20) is significantly elevated during taxane-containing chemotherapy in breast cancer patients with nonpathologic complete response. CCL20 promotes the self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) through the protein kinase Cζ (PKCζ) or p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK)-mediated activation of p65 nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathway, increasing the frequency and taxane resistance of BCSCs. Additionally, CCL20-promoted NF-κB activation increases ATP-binding cassette subfamily B member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug resistance 1 (MDR1) expression, leading to the extracellular efflux of taxane. A positive feedback loop between NF-κB and CCL20 pathways is formed, providing sustained impetus for chemoresistance in breast cancer cells. The study suggests that CCL20 can be a novel predictive marker for taxane response, and blocking CCL20 or its downstream pathway may reverse taxane resistance in breast cancer patients. Furthermore, the combination of taxane treatment and adjuvant pharmacological inhibition of ABCB1 may improve chemotherapeutic efficacy in breast cancer.
Researchers have identified a novel protein complex essential for the transport of proteins across the parasitophorous vacuole membrane (PVM) of Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite that can infect virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Toxoplasma's ability to infect and manipulate its host depends on its ability to transport "GRA" proteins into the host cell, where they can hijack host cell functions and proteins. However, the process of translocation across the PVM is not well understood.

A previous study identified a protein called TgMYR1, which is essential for the transport of GRA proteins into the host cell. To further investigate this process, researchers screened Toxoplasma mutants defective in c-Myc up-regulation for their ability to export GRA16 and GRA24 into the host cell nucleus. This led to the identification of two novel proteins, MYR2 and MYR3, which play a crucial role in the translocation of a subset of GRA proteins into the host cell.

MYR2 and MYR3 are secreted into the parasitophorous vacuole space and co-localize with the PVM and MYR1. The researchers also found that MYR3, but not MYR2, stably associates with MYR1, whose N- and C-terminal fragments are disulfide-linked. Additionally, they showed that fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to a structured DHFR domain blocks the transport of other effectors, consistent with a translocon-based model of effector transport. These findings reveal a novel complex at the PVM that is essential for effector translocation into the host cell.
Researchers have investigated the role of the origin recognition complex (ORC) in the replication of papillomaviruses (PVs). PVs, such as human papillomavirus (HPV) and bovine papillomavirus (BPV-1), have a unique replication program that involves three stages: initial amplification, cell cycle-linked maintenance, and differentiation-dependent amplification. The viral E2 protein plays a crucial role in recruiting the E1 DNA helicase to the viral origin, initiating replication. However, the involvement of ORC or other pre-replication complex (pre-RC) factors in PV replication has not been well understood.

The study found that the E2 protein of HPV and BPV-1 binds to ORC2, a component of the ORC complex. However, ORC2 was not detected at the viral origin, suggesting that it may not be necessary for the activation of the PV origin by E1 and E2. Instead, ORC2 appears to suppress the replicative function of E2. Depletion of ORC2 enhanced PV replication in a transient replication model and in keratinocytes stably maintaining viral episomes, but had no effect on copy number in a cell line with integrated HPV genomes.

The study also found that over-expression of HPV E2 decreased ORC2 occupation at two known mammalian origins of replication, suggesting that E2 restricts pre-ORC assembly that could otherwise compete for host replication complexes necessary for viral genome amplification. These findings imply that the ORC2 complex with E2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase of the viral replication program, and that elevated levels of E2 during the differentiation-dependent amplification stage subvert ORC loading and DNA synthesis at cellular origins.
Researchers investigated the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk in the urban and peri-urban area of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. A total of 564 cow milk samples were collected from 326 herds in 21 villages. Brucella DNA was detected in 10.3% of the samples using a real-time PCR test. The presence of Brucella DNA was found in both seropositive and seronegative cows, with 100% of seropositive cows and 8.3% of seronegative cows testing positive. Sequence analysis of the rpoB gene suggested that one cow was infected with Brucella abortus and another cow was likely infected with Brucella melitensis. The study highlights the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false serological negative individuals in Brucella surveillance, control, and eradication programs. The findings also suggest that vaccination of cattle with S19, in addition to vaccination of small ruminants with Rev 1, may be necessary to control Brucella infections in the livestock population. Further research is required to understand the Brucella species circulating among livestock in the region. The study's results are concerning, given the common consumption of unpasteurized dairy products in the region.
Researchers studied the role of histone H3 lysine 27 methylation (H3K27me3) in maintaining chromosome stability in the pathogenic fungus Zymoseptoria tritici. This fungus has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable and transcriptionally repressed. The researchers deleted the genes responsible for H3K27me3 and H3K9me3, a related histone modification, in Z. tritici and analyzed the effects on chromosome and genome stability. They found that the absence of H3K9me3 led to dramatic chromatin reorganization, with H3K27me3 being relocalized to regions enriched with H3K9me3 in wild-type strains. This resulted in many genome rearrangements and the formation of new chromosomes, accompanied by the activation of transposable elements. In contrast, the loss of H3K27me3 increased the stability of accessory chromosomes under normal growth conditions, without large-scale changes in gene activity. The study suggests that H3K9me3 is crucial for maintaining genome stability by preventing H3K27me3 in regions considered constitutive heterochromatin. The findings provide a basis for future studies on the influence of heterochromatin on structural genome rearrangements using Z. tritici as a model organism.
Researchers evaluated the cost-effectiveness of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) vaccination strategies for rabies in low-income countries. They found that PEP vaccination is a highly cost-effective intervention, with a cost of $200 to less than $60 per death averted. The study compared intramuscular (IM) and intradermal (ID) administration of PEP and found that switching to ID regimens could significantly reduce costs and mitigate vaccine shortages. ID administration requires less vaccine volume to treat the same number of patients, making it a more economical option for healthcare providers.

The researchers also explored financing mechanisms to make PEP more accessible and affordable for those in need. They suggest that a universal switch to ID delivery could improve the affordability and accessibility of PEP, leading to a reduction in human rabies deaths. The study highlights the importance of increasing accessibility, reducing costs, and preventing delays in the delivery of PEP, particularly in low-income countries where the burden of rabies is highest.

The researchers analyzed the costs of IM versus ID administration of PEP in different settings and under realistic constraints, such as poor compliance. They found that ID delivery of PEP is more cost-effective than IM delivery in terms of averting rabies cases and saving lives. The study also emphasizes the need to consider clinic throughput and vial sharing when evaluating the cost-effectiveness of ID administration relative to IM.
Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular parasite that infects mammalian cells, has developed a mechanism to acquire nutrients by attracting host organelles to the parasitophorous vacuole (PV) where it replicates. Research has shown that Toxoplasma exploits host lipid droplets (LD), which are fat storage organelles, to obtain lipids. The study found that Toxoplasma replication is reduced in host cells that are depleted of LD or impaired in lipid metabolism. In infected cells, the number of host LD and the expression of genes associated with LD increase, and the PV is surrounded by host LD. Toxoplasma can access lipids stored in host LD and incorporate them into its own membranes and LD. The parasite can also intercept and internalize host LD within the PV, which are then wrapped by an intravacuolar network of membranes (IVN). Mutant parasites impaired in IVN formation have a reduced capacity to take up lipids from host LD. Additionally, parasites lacking a phospholipase A2 enzyme in the IVN are less proficient in salvaging lipids from host LD. The study highlights Toxoplasma's reliance on host LD for its intracellular development and its ability to scavenge neutral lipids from host LD.
Researchers have identified chalcones, a type of flavonoid, as potential inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica, a liver fluke parasite that causes fasciolosis in cattle and sheep. Fasciolosis is an emerging zoonotic disease, meaning it can be transmitted from animals to humans, and chemotherapy is currently the main control measure available. However, resistance to the commonly used drug triclabendazole has been reported in several countries, making it essential to find new chemical entities and target molecules to control fluke infections.

A library of 40 flavonoid derivatives was screened for inhibitors of key stage-specific Fasciola hepatica cysteine proteases, FhCL3 and FhCL1. Chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups emerged as effective cathepsin L inhibitors, with one compound, C34, showing a strong binding affinity to juvenile-specific FhCL3 with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 was found to be a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the Cys-His catalytic dyad and key S2 and S3 pocket residues, determinants of the substrate specificity of this family of cysteine proteases.

In vitro studies showed that C34 reduced the ability of the parasite to migrate through the gut wall and caused a loss of motility, leading to parasite death within a week. Importantly, C34 was not cytotoxic to bovine cells, making it a promising candidate for further development as a novel agent to control fluke infection. These findings open new avenues for the development of innovative drugs to treat fasciolosis and potentially other helminthic diseases.
Researchers investigated how the visual system transmits information about changes in light intensity to the inner retina. They used in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells (BCs) transmit signals to the inner retina. The study found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is a key factor in filtering visual signals. BCs have multiple terminals of varying sizes, with smaller terminals transmitting faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher initial gain, followed by more profound adaptation. Smaller terminals are more effective at transmitting higher stimulus frequencies.

The researchers used a calcium indicator to measure the presynaptic calcium signal in BCs and found that it is a strongly rectifying function of light intensity, causing a steady increase in calcium that is graded with contrast. Voltage-dependent calcium channels in the synaptic terminal of BCs are responsible for the first major non-linear transformation of the visual signal.

The study also found that variations in filtering of the presynaptic calcium signal impact the output from the synapse. Smaller terminals respond to a step of light with higher relative release rates, but the resolution of this reporter was too low to detect modulations at stimulus frequencies above 1 Hz. The researchers used an "Adaptation Index" to quantify time-dependent changes in synaptic gain and found that the rate of vesicle release depresses more profoundly in smaller terminals.

The study's findings suggest that one neuron can transmit different temporal components in the visual signal through synaptic terminals of varying geometries with different adaptational properties.
Researchers have developed a new method for detecting and analyzing individual synapses in the brain using fluorescence microscopy. Synapses are the connections between neurons that allow them to communicate with each other, and understanding their structure and function is crucial for understanding brain function and disease. Current methods for detecting synapses, such as electron microscopy, are time-consuming and expensive, while fluorescence microscopy offers high-speed and low-cost analysis but struggles to distinguish between synaptic and non-synaptic signals.

The new method, called probabilistic fluorescence-based synapse detection, uses machine learning algorithms to analyze fluorescence microscopy images and identify synapses with high accuracy. The method was tested using data from a technique called conjugate array tomography, which provides both fluorescence and electron microscopy images of the same synapses. The results showed that the new method was able to detect synapses as accurately as human annotators, and reproduced known features of cortical synapse distributions.

This new method has the potential to revolutionize the field of neuroscience by allowing researchers to analyze large numbers of synapses quickly and accurately. It could also be used to identify new types of synapses and their density, and to study the relationships between synapses and their parent neurons. The method may also be useful for analyzing standard confocal and super-resolution fluorescence microscopy images, which are widely available but difficult to analyze using current methods. Overall, the new method provides a powerful tool for understanding the complex networks of synapses in the brain.
Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various cellular processes, including nucleic acid metabolism, gene expression, and immune system function. Impairment of zinc homeostasis can lead to various human pathologies. In mammals, zinc transport occurs through two families of transporters: ZnT and ZIP. ZnT2, a member of the ZnT family, is responsible for accumulating zinc in vesicles and secreting it into breast milk during lactation. However, the mechanism of action of ZnT2 is not well understood.

Research has suggested that ZnT2 may be coupled to the proton gradient in acidic vesicles, but this has not been conclusively established. To investigate this, the researchers modeled the mechanism of action of ZnT2 using computational and experimental methods. They found that ZnT2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter, meaning it transports zinc into vesicles in exchange for protons. This was demonstrated using functional zinc transport assays and inhibitors of the vacuolar-type proton ATPase, which alkalizes acidic vesicles.

The researchers also showed that overexpression of ZnT2 in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc led to alkalization of the vesicular pH, which was reversed by a zinc chelator. Computational energy calculations suggested that ZnT2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2H+/Zn2+ ions. This means that ZnT2 concentrates zinc in acidic vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to the cytoplasm. Overall, the study provides evidence that ZnT2 is a proton motive force-driven, electroneutral vesicular zinc exchanger.
Researchers have discovered that 14-3-3 proteins play a crucial role in maintaining genome stability by regulating the activity of Exonuclease 1 (Exo1) during DNA replication. Exo1 is an enzyme that processes stalled replication forks, which are essential for the integrity of the genome. The study found that 14-3-3 proteins interact with Exo1 in both yeast and mammalian cells, and that they help control the phosphorylation status of Exo1. Phosphorylation of Exo1 restrains its activity, and the absence of 14-3-3 proteins leads to unchecked Exo1 activity, resulting in the accumulation of single-stranded DNA gaps at stalled forks. This, in turn, causes persistent checkpoint activation and impaired recovery from DNA replication stress. The researchers also found that 14-3-3 proteins promote the progression and stability of replication forks, particularly under conditions of limited nucleotide availability. They propose that 14-3-3 proteins act as a platform for controlling Exo1 phosphorylation and activity, ensuring the proper processing of stalled replication forks. The study sheds light on the complex processes occurring at stalled replication forks and highlights the importance of 14-3-3 proteins in maintaining genome stability. Further research is needed to identify additional targets of 14-3-3 proteins and to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which they regulate Exo1 activity.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They developed a monoclonal antibody that specifically depletes pDC in lymphoid organs, allowing them to study the effects of pDC depletion on HIV-1 infection. The study found that pDC play a dual role in HIV-1 infection: they suppress HIV-1 replication by producing type I interferons (IFN-I), but also contribute to HIV-1-induced immunopathogenesis by promoting cell death of human leukocytes, including CD4 and CD8 T cells.

During acute HIV-1 infection, pDC depletion abolished the induction of IFN-I and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs), leading to increased HIV-1 replication. However, cell death induced by a highly pathogenic HIV-1 isolate was reduced in pDC-depleted mice. In chronic HIV-1 infection, pDC depletion also reduced IFN-I and ISG induction, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication. Notably, HIV-1-induced depletion of human immune cells in lymphoid organs was reduced in pDC-depleted mice, despite increased viral replication.

These findings suggest that pDC play a complex role in HIV-1 infection and pathogenesis, and that pDC depletion and IFN-I blockade may provide novel strategies for treating HIV-1-infected patients with persistent immune activation despite effective antiretroviral therapy. The study highlights the importance of understanding the role of pDC in HIV-1 infection and the potential benefits of targeting pDC in HIV-1 treatment.
Sulforaphane, a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to inhibit the infection of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in primary macrophages. Macrophages are a type of immune cell that plays a crucial role in the body's defense against pathogens. The study found that sulforaphane blocks HIV infection in macrophages, but not in primary T cells or other cell lines. This suggests that sulforaphane's anti-viral effects are specific to macrophages.

The researchers discovered that sulforaphane's anti-viral activity is mediated through the transcription regulator nuclear erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2). Nrf2 is a protein that regulates the expression of anti-oxidant genes. When sulforaphane is present, it mobilizes Nrf2, which in turn blocks HIV infection. The study found that depleting Nrf2 with siRNA increased HIV infectivity in macrophages, suggesting that Nrf2 is essential for sulforaphane's anti-viral effects.

The researchers also found that sulforaphane blocks HIV infection after reverse transcription, but before the formation of 2-LTR circles. This is similar to the mechanism of other anti-viral proteins, such as SAMHD1 and MX2, which are induced by type I interferon. However, unlike these proteins, sulforaphane does not upregulate SAMHD1 or MX2. This suggests that sulforaphane's anti-viral activity is a novel mechanism that is distinct from other known anti-viral pathways. Overall, the study provides new insights into the anti-viral effects of sulforaphane and highlights its potential as a therapeutic agent against HIV infection.
A cross-sectional study conducted in rural western Kenya investigated the prevalence and risk factors of geohelminth infections among pregnant women. The study found that 76.2% of the 390 participants who provided a stool sample were infected with at least one geohelminth species, with Ascaris lumbricoides being the most prevalent (52.3%), followed by hookworm (39.5%) and Trichuris trichiura (29.0%). Geohelminth infections were associated with the use of an unprotected water source and the lack of treatment of drinking water, but not with clinical symptoms or low body mass index.

The study also found that hookworm infection was associated with a lower mid-upper arm circumference, and hookworm infections with an egg count of 1000 or more per gram of feces were linked to lower hemoglobin levels. However, geohelminth infections were not found to have a significant impact on symptoms, anemia, or nutritional status in this population.

Interestingly, the study found that women with Ascaris lumbricoides were less likely to have malaria parasitemia compared to women without Ascaris lumbricoides, particularly among those in their second or third trimester of pregnancy. The study suggests that routine provision of antihelminth treatment during antenatal clinic visits may be beneficial, but further evaluation of the impact on pregnancy, malaria, and birth outcomes is needed.
Mycolactone, a compound produced by the skin pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been found to have anti-inflammatory effects on the nervous system. Researchers investigated whether mycolactone affects the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, which are involved in pain perception, transmission, and maintenance. The study found that mycolactone suppressed the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by these cells without affecting their viability. This effect was observed in both in vitro and in vivo experiments. In the in vivo study, mycolactone was injected into the spinal canal of rats with neuropathic pain induced by chronic constriction of the sciatic nerve. The results showed that mycolactone decreased the local production of inflammatory cytokines without inducing detectable cytotoxicity. The study suggests that mycolactone's anti-inflammatory properties may contribute to its analgesic effects. Mycolactone has previously been shown to block the Sec61-dependent production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells, which may also contribute to its analgesic effects. The findings of this study provide evidence that mycolactone suppresses the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, and support the idea that mycolactone-mediated analgesia may be partially explained by its anti-inflammatory properties.
Researchers studied the genetic factors that influence the outcome of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), a deadly disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense. The study focused on populations in Guinea, where HAT has varying clinical outcomes, ranging from rapid progression to spontaneous self-cure. The researchers analyzed genetic variations in 28 genes from 425 individuals, including 232 HAT cases, 79 individuals with latent infections, and 114 healthy controls.

The study found associations between certain genetic variations and HAT outcomes. The IL6 rs1818879 allele A was linked to a lower risk of progressing from latent infection to active disease. In contrast, the MIF rs36086171 allele G and MIF rs12483859 C allele were associated with an increased risk of latent infections. The APOL1 G2 allele (DEL) was linked to a higher risk of developing HAT, while the APOL1 G1 polymorphism was associated with a lower risk.
