The study suggests that the nuclear accumulation of these mRNAs may contribute to FXTAS pathogenesis by interfering with the neurons' ability to produce sufficient proteins to respond to cellular stress. The findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying FXTAS and highlight the potential role of Rm62 in modulating rCGG-mediated neurodegeneration.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that forms environmentally and clinically relevant biofilms, has been studied to understand the development of its extracellular matrix. The matrix, composed of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins, plays a crucial role in holding bacterial cells together. Researchers have directly visualized the product of the polysaccharide synthesis locus (Psl exopolysaccharide) at different stages of biofilm development. During attachment, Psl is anchored on the cell surface in a helical pattern, promoting cell-cell interactions and assembly of a matrix. This matrix holds bacteria in the biofilm and on the surface. Chemical dissociation of Psl from the bacterial surface disrupted the Psl matrix and the biofilm structure. During biofilm maturation, Psl accumulates on the periphery of 3-D-structured microcolonies, resulting in a Psl matrix-free cavity in the microcolony center. At the dispersion stage, swimming cells appear in this matrix cavity, and dead cells and extracellular DNA (eDNA) are concentrated in the Psl matrix-free area. Deletion of genes that control cell death and autolysis affects the formation of the matrix cavity and microcolony dispersion. These findings provide a mechanism for how P. aeruginosa builds a matrix and subsequently a cavity to free a portion of cells for seeding dispersal. The study reveals that Psl is a key scaffolding matrix component and opens up avenues for therapeutics of biofilm-related complications.
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) has the worst prognosis among solid malignancies, and new therapeutic strategies are needed to improve outcomes. Patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO) are promising tools for identifying new drugs with therapeutic potential in PDAC. To be effective, these preclinical disease models must recapitulate the molecular heterogeneity of PDAC and validate patient-specific therapeutic sensitivities. A comprehensive assessment of the genetic landscape of 16 whole-genome pairs of tumours and matched PDX, including a unique cohort of 5 'trios' of matched primary tumour, PDX, and PDO, was conducted. A pipeline was developed to score concordance between PDAC models and their paired human tumours for genomic events, including mutations, structural variations, and copy number variations. The study found that tumour-model comparisons of mutations displayed single-gene concordance across major PDAC driver genes, but relatively poor agreement across the greater mutational load. Genome-wide and chromosome-centric analysis of structural variation (SV) events highlighted previously unrecognized concordance across chromosomes that demonstrate clustered SV events. The study also found that polyploidy presented a major challenge when assessing copy number changes, but ploidy-corrected copy number states suggest good agreement between donor-model pairs. Overall, the study highlights that while PDXs and PDOs may serve as tractable and transplantable systems for probing the molecular properties of PDAC, these models may best serve selective analyses across different levels of genomic complexity.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) to identify genetic factors contributing to breast cancer in East-Asian women. The study included 19,091 cases and 20,606 controls from China, Korea, and Japan. After analyzing over 690,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the researchers identified a novel susceptibility locus represented by SNP rs9485372, located near the TGF-β activated kinase (TAB2) gene on chromosome 6q25.1. This SNP showed a consistent association with breast cancer risk across all four stages of the study, with a P-value of 3.8×10−12 in the combined analysis of all samples. The adjusted odds ratios for the A/G and A/A genotypes were 0.89 (0.85-0.94) and 0.80 (0.75-0.86), respectively, compared to the G/G genotype. Two other SNPs, rs9383951 and rs7107217, located in the ESR1 gene and 11q24.3, respectively, also showed a consistent association with breast cancer risk in each of the four stages. These findings provide strong evidence for a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus represented by rs9485372 and identify two possible susceptibility loci in the ESR1 gene and 11q24.3. The study contributes to the understanding of genetic factors contributing to breast cancer in East-Asian women and highlights the importance of further research to identify additional susceptibility loci.
Researchers studied 230 Cryptococcus neoformans isolates from HIV-positive patients in South Africa with cryptococcal meningitis, a major cause of mortality in the developing world. They used multi-locus sequence typing (MLST) and in vitro phenotypic virulence assays to analyze the genetic diversity and virulence of the isolates. The study found high levels of genetic diversity among the isolates, with 50 different sequence types identified, including 18 novel types. The isolates were grouped into three main molecular types: VNI, VNII, and VNB.

The researchers found that the VNB lineage was associated with significantly worse survival rates, with a 3.35-fold increased risk of death compared to other lineages. This association remained significant even after adjusting for known prognostic indicators and treatment regimens. The study also found that the VNII lineage had increased laccase activity and ex vivo CSF survival, indicating increased virulence. These findings suggest that Cryptococcus neoformans is a phenotypically heterogeneous pathogen, and that lineage plays a significant role in cryptococcal virulence during human infection.

The study's results highlight the importance of understanding the genetic diversity of Cryptococcus neoformans in Southern Africa, where the pathogen is a major public health concern. The findings have implications for the development of targeted treatments and prevention strategies for cryptococcal meningitis. Further research is needed to investigate how genetic diversity is structured across African environments and to assess the risks posed by different ecotypes of the pathogen.
Researchers have identified the transcription factor Tec1 as the last component of the newly evolved signal transduction pathway that regulates the pheromone response of the white cell phenotype in Candida albicans, an opportunistic human fungal pathogen. This discovery provides a comprehensive description of the pheromone response pathway in the white cell phenotype of C. albicans and sheds light on how new signal transduction pathways may evolve. The pathway appears to have been derived from three different ancestral programs still functional in C. albicans: the upstream portion from the opaque pheromone response pathway of the mating process, Tec1 from a filamentation pathway, and the white-specific downstream target genes from an ancestral biofilm process. The evolution of this pheromone response pathway in C. albicans may serve as a paradigm for how signal transduction pathways evolve. The researchers used an overexpression library of 107 transcription factors and mutational analyses to identify Tec1 as the transcription factor targeted by the MAP kinase pathway. The white cell pheromone response pathway in C. albicans is a "young" pathway, meaning it has had insufficient time to duplicate, replace, or modify components in response to new selective pressures or changing roles, providing a unique glimpse into the evolution of a new signal transduction pathway.
Researchers investigated the variation in genomic GC-content among 149 bacterial species, which ranges from less than 20% to more than 70%. They tested the hypothesis that this variation is due to differences in mutation patterns between bacteria. The study found a significant excess of GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations in GC-rich bacteria, but not in AT-rich bacteria. This pattern was observed across a broad range of phylogenetically diverse species. The researchers ruled out the possibility that this excess is due to mutation bias, as it would imply that GC-rich bacteria are declining in GC-content, which is unsustainable. They also found that the pattern is unlikely due to translational selection or biased gene conversion, as optimal codons tend to be AT-rich and the excess of GC→AT SNPs is observed in datasets with no evidence of recombination. As a result, the study concludes that there is selection to increase synonymous GC-content in many species. Since synonymous GC-content is highly correlated with genomic GC-content, the researchers further conclude that there is selection on genomic base composition in many bacteria.
Researchers have developed a new tool to help control soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in Kenya. These infections, caused by hookworm, Ascaris lumbricoides, and Trichuris trichiura, are a major public health concern in the country. To guide control efforts, the researchers created maps showing the combined prevalence of STH infections across Kenya in 1989 and 2009. They used data from 106,370 individuals from 945 surveys conducted between 1974 and 2009, as well as ecological and climatic information from satellite data.

The researchers used Bayesian space-time geostatistical models to estimate the probability of STH infection prevalence exceeding 20% in different areas of the country. They found that in most areas, the prevalence was below the 20% threshold in 2009, but there were areas around Lake Victoria and the coast where the prevalence was higher. By comparing the maps for 1989 and 2009, the researchers observed a gradual decrease in STH prevalence over time.

The model estimated that approximately 2.8 million school-age children live in districts that require mass treatment. The researchers suggest that a quarter of Kenya's school-aged children live in areas with high STH prevalence, warranting mass treatment. This tool can be used to refine decision-making in helminth control as control efforts are successful in reducing infection levels.
Researchers investigated the role of innate immune cells, specifically invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells, in controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. They found that iNKT cells can recognize Mtb-infected macrophages and produce interferon-γ (IFN-γ), a cytokine that activates macrophages and helps control bacterial replication. This innate control of bacterial replication is dependent on CD1d-restricted iNKT cells, which require CD1d expression by infected macrophages and the presence of IL-12 and IL-18 to be activated. The researchers also showed that even small numbers of iNKT cells are sufficient to restrict Mtb replication. To determine if iNKT cells contribute to host defense against tuberculosis in vivo, the researchers adoptively transferred iNKT cells into mice infected with virulent Mtb. They found that primary splenic iNKT cells from uninfected mice significantly reduced the bacterial burden in the lungs of infected mice. This is the first evidence that CD1d-restricted NKT cells mediate protection against Mtb in vivo. The study suggests that iNKT cells have a direct bactericidal effect, even in the absence of synthetic ligands such as α-galactosylceramide.
Researchers have investigated the process of protein cross-linking in Bacillus subtilis endospores, which are highly resilient cells surrounded by a complex protein coat. The protein coat is stabilized by covalent bonds formed by a transglutaminase enzyme called Tgl. Unlike other transglutaminases, Tgl is produced in an active form, raising questions about how its activity is controlled during spore coat assembly.

The study found that the substrates assembled onto the spore coat before Tgl production determine its localization to the surface of the developing spore. The researchers identified specific docking sites on the substrates that are crucial for Tgl's localization. They also showed that Tgl becomes part of the cross-linked products during the reaction, suggesting that it "spotwelds" pre-formed assemblies together.

The study suggests that the dependency of Tgl on its substrates is used to control the time, location, and extent of its activity. This ensures that pre-assembled complexes are cross-linked at the spore surface. The researchers propose that this mechanism is essential for proper temporal and spatial control of spore coat protein cross-linking, as well as specificity and the extent of Tgl's action. This mechanism may also apply to Tgl orthologues in other spore-forming bacteria. Overall, the study provides new insights into the regulation of protein cross-linking in Bacillus subtilis endospores and highlights the importance of substrate-dependent localization in controlling enzyme activity.
A study conducted in southern Lao PDR aimed to map the distribution of Opisthorchis viverrini, a food-borne trematode species that causes biliary diseases and cholangiocarcinoma, and identify underlying risk factors. A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was carried out in 51 villages in Champasack province in 2007. The study found that 61.1% of 3,371 participants were infected with O. viverrini. Geostatistical models identified age, Lao Loum ethnic group, educational attainment, occupation, and unsafe drinking water source as risk factors for infection, while history of praziquantel treatment, access to sanitation, and distance to freshwater bodies were found to be protective factors. Spatial patterns of O. viverrini were mainly governed by environmental factors, with predictive modeling identifying two different risk profiles: low risk in the mountains and high risk in the Mekong corridor. The study presents the first risk map of O. viverrini infection in Champasack province, which is essential for spatial targeting of control efforts. The findings suggest that infection with O. viverrini is strongly associated with exposure to the second intermediate host fish, human behavior, and culture, while high transmission is sustained by the lack of sanitation. The study highlights the importance of environmental factors in predicting O. viverrini prevalence and emphasizes the need for urgent public health interventions to address the high prevalence of O. viverrini infection in the region.
In the city of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, drains play a significant role in the larval development of mosquitoes that transmit lymphatic filariasis and malaria. The city's extensive drain network, often with inadequate water flow and blocked by waste, creates an ideal breeding ground for Anopheles and Culex larvae. A study analyzed data from the Urban Malaria Control Program and a 2006 drain survey to identify the importance of drains as larval habitats. The results showed that over 70% of larval habitats in Dar es Salaam are human-made, with drains being the most common type, accounting for 42% of all aquatic habitats. Drains with stagnant water were found to have a significantly higher presence of Anopheles and Culex larvae compared to those with flowing water. Vegetation was also found to be positively associated with the presence of mosquito larvae. The study suggests that restoring and maintaining drains in Dar es Salaam has the potential to eliminate over 40% of all potential mosquito larval habitats currently treated with larvicides. The findings highlight the importance of human-made larval habitats for both lymphatic filariasis and malaria vectors, underscoring the need for a synergy between ongoing control efforts for these diseases.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection leads to changes in lipid-related metabolites in the endoplasmic reticulum of infected cells, which are associated with the formation of replicative complexes. Research has shown that DENV infection inhibits the phosphorylation of HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR), an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, resulting in a cholesterol-enriched cellular environment that favors viral replication. This study found that DENV infection increases the activity of HMGCR, which is associated with the inactivation of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK). AMPK activation by metformin reduced HMGCR activity, suggesting that AMPK inactivation mediates the enhanced activity of HMGCR. The study also found that HMGCR and cholesterol co-localized with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E, indicating a role for HMGCR and AMPK activity in the formation of DENV replicative complexes. Metformin and lovastatin, an HMGCR inhibitor, disrupted this co-localization and replicative complex formation, supporting the idea that active HMGCR is required for replicative complex formation. Furthermore, metformin showed a dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV-infected cells, while compound C, an AMPK inhibitor, increased viral genome copies and the percentage of infected cells. These findings suggest that DENV infection increases HMGCR activity through AMPK inactivation, leading to higher cholesterol levels in the endoplasmic reticulum necessary for replicative complex formation. This study provides new insights into the mechanisms involved in host lipid metabolism during DENV replication and identifies new potential antiviral targets for DENV replication.
Researchers have developed a new approach to understand the process of tRNA translocation on the ribosome, a crucial step in protein synthesis. By using all-atom molecular dynamics simulations, they were able to bridge the gap between kinetic measurements and the energy landscape of the ribosome. This allowed them to estimate the free-energy barriers associated with tRNA translocation. The study found that the process can be decomposed into slow, large-scale collective movements and rapid local fluctuations. The researchers identified specific regions of the ribosome that undergo these movements, including the 30S-body rotation, 30S-head swivel, and tRNA displacements. These motions are essential for substrate translocation and protein elongation in the cell. The study provides a quantitative framework for understanding and interpreting data related to tRNA translocation, which can be applied to other biological processes. The findings suggest that the ribosome functions as a "thermal ratchet machine," where random energetic fluctuations lead to large-scale diffusive configurational rearrangements. The researchers used single-molecule methods to project the free energy onto specific coordinates, allowing them to establish a quantitative bridge between state-like kinetic measurements and the continuous energy landscape. This approach provides a unifying foundation for understanding the dynamics of the ribosome and its role in protein synthesis.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC), a rare type of thyroid cancer. They analyzed tissue samples from 84 MTC patients and found 101 genetic mutations in 18 different genes. The most common mutation was in the ret proto-oncogene, which occurred in 47 cases. Other frequently mutated genes included those encoding Harvey rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, serine/threonine kinase 11, and v-kit Hardy-Zuckerman 4 feline sarcoma viral oncogene homolog.

The researchers also looked for anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangements in the MTC samples. Two out of 98 samples tested positive for ALK rearrangement. Further analysis revealed two types of ALK fusions: glutamine:fructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GFPT1)-ALK and echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4)-ALK. The EML4-ALK fusion was found in a metastatic MTC case that showed a significant response to the ALK inhibitor crizotinib. This suggests that the EML4-ALK fusion may be a potential driver mutation and a valid target for ALK inhibitors.

The study also identified several other genetic mutations in MTC, including RET, RAS, and MET mutations. These mutations were found in both sporadic and familial MTC cases. The researchers conclude that their findings provide new insights into the genetic landscape of MTC and highlight the potential for targeted therapies, such as ALK inhibitors, in treating this type of cancer.
Researchers conducted a study in Malda district, West Bengal, India, to understand the role of asymptomatic leishmaniasis in the spread of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL). Asymptomatic cases were identified through active mass surveys in eight tribal villages using rapid diagnostic kits. Out of 2,603 individuals screened, 185 tested positive for antileishmanial antibodies, with 96 having a history of VL/PKDL and 89 without such a history. Seventy-nine individuals were classified as asymptomatic leishmaniasis cases, and 10 were diagnosed with active VL. The ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic cases was 7.9:1.

The researchers followed up with the asymptomatic cases for three years to observe sero-conversion and disease transformation. During this period, 8 out of 77 (10.39%) asymptomatic cases developed symptoms of VL, while 62 (80.52%) showed sero-conversion. Seven individuals remained seropositive after three years. The study found that asymptomatic cases can progress to clinical disease at any time up to three years after the initial survey. The researchers emphasize that the presence of asymptomatic cases does not guarantee that an area is free from leishmaniasis, as symptomatic VL or PKDL can appear even after three years.

The study highlights the importance of addressing asymptomatic cases in the VL elimination program initiated by three neighboring endemic countries. The prevalence rate of asymptomatic leishmaniasis in the study area was 3.16%, which is lower than rates reported in other studies in Bihar. The findings suggest that asymptomatic infected individuals require attention to prevent future epidemics.
Researchers have developed a new technique called Multiplex Ligation-Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze genetic rearrangements in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. These rearrangements, known as gross chromosomal rearrangements (GCRs), can lead to genetic diseases and cancer. The study found that the introduction of a repetitive retrotransposon called Ty912 onto a nonessential chromosome arm of S. cerevisiae led to increased genome instability, primarily due to the formation of monocentric nonreciprocal translocations.

Using MLPA, the researchers analyzed a large number of GCRs and found that the distribution of translocations induced by Ty912 was nonrandom. They discovered that the majority of these translocations were mediated by only six translocation targets on four different chromosomes, despite the presence of 254 potential Ty-related translocation targets in the S. cerevisiae genome. The study also found that the majority of Ty912-mediated translocations resulted from RAD52-dependent recombination, but a significant number of nonreciprocal translocations were mediated by RAD52-independent recombination between Ty1 elements.

Furthermore, the researchers found that defects in the acetylation of histone H3 lysine residue 56 (H3K56) resulted in increased accumulation of GCRs and whole-chromosome duplications, leading to aneuploidy. The study suggests that MLPA is a versatile technique for the rapid analysis of GCRs and can facilitate the genetic analysis of the pathways that prevent and promote GCRs and aneuploidy.
Researchers have developed a new method for predicting how proteins interact with each other, a process known as protein docking. This method, called Semi-Definite programming-based Underestimation (SDU), uses a mathematical approach to find the most likely position and orientation of two proteins in space. The method is based on the idea that the interaction between proteins is driven by a "free energy funnel," a concept similar to how proteins fold into their native shape.

The SDU method uses a combination of rigid body motions and flexibility of the proteins' interface side chains to find the optimal position and orientation of the proteins. However, applying this method directly to the space of rotations and translations is challenging due to its geometry. To overcome this, the researchers introduced a new strategy that separates the search space into three independent variables: side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance, and five angular descriptors of the relative orientations of the molecules.

This approach allows the method to efficiently explore the free energy surface spanned by encounter complexes, which are local free energy minima. The results show that the SDU strategy can generate docking predictions with high accuracy, with an average ligand interface Cα root-mean-square deviation of less than 5 Å, while achieving a 20-fold efficiency gain compared to Monte Carlo methods. The successful application of SDU to protein docking further validates the assumption that the free energy landscape of the complex is a funnel in some neighborhood of the native state.
